lecture 7: Exponential and Logarithmic Functions — Graphs, Domain and Range, Discontinuities, and Infinity Behavior

Exponential Functions

1. What Is an Exponential Function?

An exponential function has the form:

f(x)=axf(x) = a^x f(x)=ax

Where:

  • a>0a > 0a>0 and a≠1a \neq 1a=1
  • xxx is any real number

Example: f(x)=2xf(x) = 2^xf(x)=2x, f(x)=10xf(x) = 10^xf(x)=10x, f(x)=exf(x) = e^xf(x)=ex

2. Real-World Examples

  • Bacteria growth: population doubles every hour
  • Finance: compound interest over time
  • Physics: radioactive decay

These all grow (or decay) exponentially — very fast!

3. Graph and Behavior

Function Graph Shape Domain Range Discontinuities
f(x)=axf(x) = a^xf(x)=ax (for a>1a > 1a>1) Grows rapidly R\mathbb{R}R (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞) None
f(x)=axf(x) = a^xf(x)=ax (for 0<a<10 < a < 10<a<1) Decreases rapidly R\mathbb{R}R (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞) None

Horizontal asymptote at y=0y = 0y=0

Graph of 2x2^x2x and 0.4x0.4^x0.4x

Logarithmic Functions

1. What Is a Logarithm?

A logarithm is the inverse of an exponential function.

log⁡b(x)=y  ⟺  by=x\log_b(x) = y \iff b^y = x logb​(x)=y⟺by=x

  • b>0b > 0b>0, b≠1b \neq 1b=1
  • Most common: log⁡10(x)\log_{10}(x)log10​(x), log⁡2(x)\log_{2}(x)log2​(x), and ln⁡(x)\ln(x)ln(x) (natural log, base eee)

2. Graph and Behavior

Function Graph Shape Domain Range Discontinuities
f(x)=log⁡b(x) for b>1f(x) = \log_b(x) \text{ for } b > 1f(x)=logb​(x) for b>1 Increases slowly (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞) R\mathbb{R}R Vertical asymptote at x=0x = 0x=0
f(x)=log⁡b(x) for 0<b<1f(x) = \log_b(x) \text{ for } 0 < b < 1f(x)=logb​(x) for 0<b<1 Decreases slowly (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞) R\mathbb{R}R Vertical asymptote at x=0x = 0x=0

No output for x≤0x \leq 0x≤0

Graph of log⁡2(x)\log_2(x)log2​(x) and log⁡0.4(x)\log_{0.4}(x)log0.4​(x)

Domain and Range Summary

Function Domain Range
f(x)=axf(x) = a^xf(x)=ax R\mathbb{R}R (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞)
f(x)=log⁡b(x)f(x) = \log_b(x)f(x)=logb​(x) (0,∞)(0, \infty)(0,∞) R\mathbb{R}R

Infinity Behavior

Exponential Growth

  • If a>1a > 1a>1:
    f(x)=ax→∞f(x) = a^x \to \inftyf(x)=ax→∞ as x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞,
    f(x)→0f(x) \to 0f(x)→0 as x→−∞x \to -\inftyx→−∞

Exponential Decay

  • If 0<a<10 < a < 10<a<1:
    f(x)→0f(x) \to 0f(x)→0 as x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞,
    f(x)→∞f(x) \to \inftyf(x)→∞ as x→−∞x \to -\inftyx→−∞

Logarithmic Behavior

f(x)=log⁡b(x)f(x) = \log_b(x)f(x)=logb​(x)

  • If b>1b > 1b>1:
    f(x)→∞f(x) \to \inftyf(x)→∞ as x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞
    f(x)→−∞f(x) \to -\inftyf(x)→−∞ as x→0+x \to 0^+x→0+

  • If 0<b<10 < b < 10<b<1:
    f(x)→−∞f(x) \to -\inftyf(x)→−∞ as x→∞x \to \inftyx→∞
    f(x)→∞f(x) \to \inftyf(x)→∞ as x→0+x \to 0^+x→0+

Discontinuities and Asymptotes

1. Exponential Functions

  • No discontinuities
  • Horizontal asymptote: y=0y = 0y=0
  • Smooth and continuous everywhere

2. Logarithmic Functions

  • Essential discontinuity (vertical asymptote) at x=0x = 0x=0
  • Not defined for x≤0x \leq 0x≤0
  • No removable discontinuities

Logarithmic Properties

All rules and properties are valid for any base b>0b > 0b>0 and b≠1b \neq 1b=1, and can be proven using the definition of logarithms (by=x  ⟺  log⁡b(x)=yb^y = x \iff \log_b(x) = yby=x⟺logb​(x)=y).

  • log⁡b(1)=0\log_b(1) = 0logb​(1)=0
  • log⁡b(b)=1\log_b(b) = 1logb​(b)=1
  • log⁡b(bx)=x\log_b(b^x) = xlogb​(bx)=x
  • blog⁡b(x)=xb^{\log_b(x)} = xblogb​(x)=x

Rules of logarithms:

  • log⁡b(xy)=log⁡b(x)+log⁡b(y)\log_b(xy) = \log_b(x) + \log_b(y)logb​(xy)=logb​(x)+logb​(y)
  • log⁡b(x/y)=log⁡b(x)−log⁡b(y)\log_b(x/y) = \log_b(x) - \log_b(y)logb​(x/y)=logb​(x)−logb​(y)
  • log⁡b(xk)=klog⁡b(x)\log_b(x^k) = k \log_b(x)logb​(xk)=klogb​(x)

Change of base formula:

  • log⁡b(x)=log⁡k(x)log⁡k(b)\log_b(x) = \frac{\log_k(x)}{\log_k(b)}logb​(x)=logk​(b)logk​(x)​

Regular Exercises

1. Calculate the following

a) What is log⁡2(8)\log_2(8)log2​(8)?








Think: 2 raised to what power equals 8?


b) What is log⁡3(19)\log_3\left(\frac{1}{9}\right)log3​(91​)?








Think: 3 raised to what power equals 1/9?


c) What is 2log⁡2(5)2^{\log_2(5)}2log2​(5)?








This is testing the inverse relationship between exponentials and logarithms


d) What is 4log⁡2(3)4^{\log_2(3)}4log2​(3)?








Think: 2 raised to what power equals 3?


2. Domain and Range Practice

Determine the domain and range of each:

  • a) f(x)=3x2−4f(x) = 3^{x^2-4}f(x)=3x2−4
  • b) f(x)=log⁡10(x2−1)f(x) = \log_{10}(x^2 - 1)f(x)=log10​(x2−1)
  • c) f(x)=log⁡10(2−x)f(x) = \log_{10}(2 - x)f(x)=log10​(2−x)

3. Prove Logarithmic Properties

Use the definition log⁡b(x)=y  ⟺  by=x\log_b(x) = y \iff b^y = xlogb​(x)=y⟺by=x to prove the following properties:

  • a) log⁡b(xy)=log⁡b(x)+log⁡b(y)\log_b(xy) = \log_b(x) + \log_b(y)logb​(xy)=logb​(x)+logb​(y)
  • b) log⁡b(x/y)=log⁡b(x)−log⁡b(y)\log_b(x/y) = \log_b(x) - \log_b(y)logb​(x/y)=logb​(x)−logb​(y)
  • c) log⁡b(xk)=klog⁡b(x)\log_b(x^k) = k \log_b(x)logb​(xk)=klogb​(x)

4. Bacteria Growth

A scientist is growing a bacteria culture in a lab. At the start, there are 100 bacteria. The population doubles every 3 hours.

Questions:

  • a) Write an exponential function P(t)P(t)P(t) that models the population after ttt hours.

  • b) How many bacteria will there be after 12 hours?

  • c) After how many hours will the population reach at least 6,400 bacteria?

5. Solve the exponential equation

Solve for xxx:

52x=5x+1−65^{2x} = 5^{x+1} - 6 52x=5x+1−6

6. Solve the logarithmic equation

Solve for xxx:

4log⁡3(x2)−log⁡3(x)=144 \log_3(x^2) - \log_3(x) = 14 4log3​(x2)−log3​(x)=14

Extra Advanced Exercises

1. Exponential and Logarithmic Equation Combo

Solve for ( x ):

2x=5x−12^x = 5^{x - 1} 2x=5x−1

2. Domain Puzzle: Log of a Log

Find the domain of:

f(x)=log⁡2(log⁡3(x−1))f(x) = \log_2(\log_3(x - 1)) f(x)=log2​(log3​(x−1))

3. Change of base formula.

Prove the change of base formula for the log function:

log⁡b(x)=log⁡k(x)log⁡k(b)\log_b(x) = \frac{\log_k(x)}{\log_k(b)}logb​(x)=logk​(b)logk​(x)​
